channel.title: miljko tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from miljko.

item.description: üìö On regression to the mean in Fooled by Randomness. Beware the uncontrolled phase 2 data, especially ones with surprisingly large effect sizes. https://t.co/Oj7mt4gNKb

CDC community transmission map for the last month. BA.5 was 9.6% on 6/4 and became the dominant strain at 53.5% on 7/2, per https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj. So, unless the CDC changes category thresholds or adds a purple ‚Äúultra high‚Äù category this won‚Äôt tell us anything about BA.5. https://t.co/H8OKWNjnNl

@tmprowell @trishankkarthik For a while now the likelihood of infection without precautions has been 100%, conditional on not dying of other causes. To be clear, that‚Äôs terrible and was completely avoidable (though hard to say when we crossed the threshold). So in that sense, aren‚Äôt levels more informative?
@tmprowell @trishankkarthik To that effect, here is the time lapse of the past month for covid *transmission* levels. BA.5 didn't become dominant until 7/2 per CDC (https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj) and was <10% when the time lapse started so how much more information can we get out of transmission alone? https://t.co/royAsX9zbx
@tmprowell @trishankkarthik This is the main source of my confusion. Should we base our choices on what the CDC says or what your original tweet shows? https://t.co/KsjYl9m6iN

@trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. But there is a wide chasm between that statement and claims made in the Forever Plague article, and there is some evidence that refutes those claims that should have been at least mentioned.
@tmprowell Please see my response.

@tmprowell @trishankkarthik Got it! Your tweet was about community levels though, not transmission, which is what got me confused. Apologies for getting that part wrong!!! Still, good practice to have date+source on any graph, for this reason.
@trishankkarthik @EricTopol There is actual evidence against the claim, not just lack of evidence: https://t.co/4XLkEhgkm3
@timtriche That is‚Ä¶ completely bonkers. Again, what are they thinking?

@trishankkarthik The tweet was posted yesterday but shows a CDC community transmission map from a period when transmission was high (note that there is no source or date on the all-red map). The actual community transmission level (2nd screenshot) is generally low.
This tweet needs a disinformation flag the size of a barn. What on Earth are people thinking? *Are* they thinking? https://t.co/GsO6Q6KQWH

Incredible how many poorly reasoned articles about covid, such as the one below, list @EricTopol as a source. Behind every bad argument lies a weasel word ambiguous enough not to be flagged as disinformation but explicit enough to trigger bad reasoning. https://t.co/hhOqYPKph7
üìö Halfway through Fooled by Randomness, the seeds of Antifragile. It‚Äôs all one work, all that‚Äôs missing is cross-references from earlier to latter written parts. https://t.co/Jb3LJe6H9K

Pre-prints, anecdotes, and substack posts full of wishy-washy weaselly words transmitting much speculation and no actual information (looking at you, Topol). Speculation that crumbles after even a cursory look at actual dataüëá https://t.co/0u3Vdl5vqu
@trishankkarthik @nntaleb No, no, you don‚Äôt understand. We learned so much from our predecessors‚Äô mistakes, so this time it‚Äôs different! (as in, a different particular path to ruin)
@trishankkarthik @nntaleb Hah, yes. The Black Swan (book) turned most black swans gray, at least to those who read it.

üìö Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness. If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. https://t.co/9dS3tchf95

Study below doesn't address it directly, but remember that miracle drug you read about in a tweet, the one that cured some mice according to the aÃ∂rÃ∂tÃ∂iÃ∂cÃ∂lÃ∂eÃ∂ pÃ∂rÃ∂eÃ∂pÃ∂rÃ∂iÃ∂nÃ∂tÃ∂ press release? The probability it reaches approval is much, much, much (‚Ä¶) more modest than you think. https://t.co/8RjDkGda9G

@vinamrsachdeva ‚Ä¶unless those others have medical conditions for which they need to be in the hospital and can‚Äôt lose access to health care. Hospitals were already operating near capacity in the name of efficiency.

Vest o tvitu koji je prevod drugog tvita koji prepriƒçava blog post koji iznosi puno spekulacija ali ni jednu informaciju o te≈æini bolesti koju izaziva omikron ba.5. Pa bravo. https://t.co/9ZOyfDWsY7
@framptonsoaps In spring 2020? How‚Äôs your reading comprehension?
Reminded again today that the median Twitter account has intellectual rigor of a wet noodle and subtlety of a drunken luchador. Truly a wonderful place.
@pmontu33 Hope I‚Äôll be able to say the same (word for word) next year!
@TeaRespecter The whole world locked down in March https://t.co/onq4WOEr9b But you didn‚Äôt answer my question.

@GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else‚Äôs, I don‚Äôt care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren‚Äôt justified ex ante? Because the only thing I‚Äôve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).
